1.NAME: AO-Cat
1.DESCRIPTION: The AO-Cat Ontology is a formal ontology of the resources managed by the ARIADNE Research Infrastructure, ARIADNE RI. AO-Cat was developed within the ARIADNEplus project. AO-Cat, inherits the CIDOC CRM model and philosophy to provide the community with a powerful and efficient integration tool, capable of capturing the meaning of a diverse range of archaeological data sets offered by content providers and integrating their data in a unique and coherent way.  The aim of the AO-Cat is to present a core ontology to which data providers map their individual database schema, thereby ensuring interoperability between diverse resources. It is capable of being deployed at the “site” or “monument” level, but also effectively implemented at item level, e.g. for individual artefacts or graves, providing a much more granular level of interoperability. ARIADNE resource types can be used in the portal to filter at different levels.
1.DOCUMENTATION:
- The AO-Cat Ontology: https://zenodo.org/records/7818375

- ARIADNEplus D4.3 – Final report on dataset integration\
  https://zenodo.org/records/7612672

- ARIADNEplus Data Aggregation Pipeline: User Guide\
  https://zenodo.org/records/8060925

2.NAME: SKOS
2.DESCRIPTION: SKOS (Simple Knowledge Organization System)  is the most known and widely used schema for formally representing thesauri and other classification schemes and types of structured controlled vocabularies. SKOS is a W3C recommendation and part of the Semantic Web family of standards built upon RDF and RDFS, and its main objective is to enable easy publication and use of such vocabularies as linked data. It defines a set of classes and properties sufficient to represent the common features found in a standard thesaurus. It is based on a concept-centric view of the vocabulary, where primitive objects are not terms, but abstract notions represented by terms .

3.NAME: CIDOC CRM
3.PROVIDER: CIDOC - ICOM International Committee for Documentation
3.DESCRIPTION: The CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model (CRM) is a powerful tool for integrating information in the cultural heritage sector. It facilitates the exploration of complex historical questions across diverse datasets by providing formal definitions and structures for describing implicit and explicit concepts and relationships. Developed over two decades and recognized as an ISO standard (ISO 21127:2014), the CIDOC CRM serves as a common semantic framework, enabling the integration of data from various sources such as museums, libraries, and archives. Its modular extensions complement the base ontology, supporting specialized research and ensuring high levels of information integrity and compatibility.

4.NAME: CRMarchaeo
4.CREATOR: CIDOC CRM Special Interest Group (SIG)
4.DESCRIPTION: CRMarchaeo is an ontological extension of the CIDOC CRM, specifically designed to document and manage archaeological data, particularly excavation processes. It introduces additional classes and relationships to capture archaeological entities and their context, such as stratigraphy, artefacts, and excavation activities. It builds on existing cultural heritage standards and models while extending principles from CRMsci, especially regarding stratigraphic and geological information.

158.NAME: CRMinf
158.CREATOR: CIDOC CRM Special Interest Group (SIG)
158.DESCRIPTION: CRMinf is an ontological extension of the CIDOC CRM, specifically designed to document and manage scientific reasonning processes. It introduces additional classes and relationships to capture argumentation and inference making in descriptive and empirical sciences such as biodiversity, geology, geography, archaeology, cultural heritage, conservation, research IT environments and research data libraries. It builds on existing CIDOC CRM core model while extending also CRMsci for observation descriptions.

5.NAME: CRMdig
5.DESCRIPTION: CRM Digital is an ontology and RDF Schema to encode metadata about the steps and methods of production ("provenance") of digitization products and synthetic digital representations such as 2D, 3D or even animated Models created by various technologies. Its distinct features compared to competitive models is the complete inclusion of the initial physical measurement processes and their parameters. It has been developed as compatible extension of CIDOC CRM, which allows for querying the most relevant facts and returning complete descriptions encoded in this model by generic ISO21127 terms without need to refer to its specific properties. In contrast, competitive models cannot be queried by a more general standard and are restricted to the computational provenance only. Data encoded in the major competitive models can be transformed without loss of meaning into a CRM-Digital-form.

6.NAME: CRMtex
6.DESCRIPTION: CRMtex is an extension of CIDOC CRM created to support the study of ancient documents by identifying relevant textual entities and by modelling the scientific process related with the investigation of ancient texts and their features in order to foster integration with other cultural heritage research fields, such as archaeology and history. The concept of “written text”, introduced by the extension, is intended to identify a common entity consisting in a particular feature (i.e., set of glyphs) created (i.e., written) on various kinds of support, having semiotic significance and the declared purpose of conveying a specific message towards a given recipient or group of recipients. The modelling of the scientific autoptic examination of the document, consisting of an accurate analysis of the surface and the signs and prescribing the use of specific tools and procedures, is another key aspect taken into account by the extension.
6.USED IN:
ARIADNE Portal:  https://portal.ariadne-infrastructure.eu/
Languages and Cultures of Ancient Italy: https://www.unifi.it/p-doc2-2015-0-A-2c303a2d322f-0.html

7.NAME: CRMsci
7.DESCRIPTION: The Scientific Observation Model (CRMsci) is a formal ontology designed to serve as a global schema for integrating metadata about scientific observations, measurements, and processed data in various descriptive and empirical sciences, including biodiversity, geology, geography, archaeology, and cultural heritage conservation. Its primary goal is to facilitate the management, integration, mediation, interchange, and access to research data by describing semantic relationships, particularly causal ones. CRMsci extends the CIDOC CRM (ISO21127) as a general ontology of human activity, things, and events occurring in spacetime, using the same encoding-neutral formalism of knowledge representation. This model can be implemented in various forms, such as RDFS, OWL, and RDBMS. By reusing parts of the CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model, CRMsci ensures comprehensive integration and provides a list of all constructs used from ISO21127, following version 6.2 maintained by CIDOC.

8.NAME: Epigraphic Ontology
8.DESCRIPTION:
Epigraphic Ontology describes how to use existing ontologies as well as a few new properties and
classes, to model epigraphic objects. Inscriptions that are described using this model can be
shared, ingested into an ontological database, and used in graph databases or to share linked
open data. Describing an inscription in this way complements existing practices as described by
EpiDoc.

9.NAME: The EAGLE Vocabularies
9.PROVIDER: EAGLE (Europeana network of Ancient Greek and Latin Epigraphy)
9.DESCRIPTION: The EAGLE Vocabularies, developed by the EAGLE project's Working Group 1 – GIS and Terminologies, serve as authoritative lists and controlled vocabularies for descriptive fields within the EAGLE Metadata Model. These vocabularies encompass terms from the EAGLE BPN and translations from the EpiDoc consortium and other partners, providing stable identifiers, inter-term relations, and accessibility for third-party use and reuse. Their development aims to facilitate alignment with external resources, such as LIMC France and Wikidata, while encouraging contributions to enrich the resource with term definitions, conceptual elucidation, and new translations.

11.NAME: TRIPLE Ontology
11.DESCRIPTION:
It consists of a formal representation of GoTriple data model. GoTriple entities consist of documents (the most relevant content), projects and authors. The Data Model is largeky based on Schema.org. An effort has been made to make interoperable the controlled vocabularies used for describing some of the the documents attributes (disciplines, licences, content types, conditions of access).
NOTE: its completion is one of Net7's contribution in ATRIUM

12.NAME: TRIPLE Vocabulary
12.DESCRIPTION: The Triple Vocabulary is a multilingual and hierarchical set of 3.375 SSH-related concepts. It is a subset of LCSH (Library of Congress Subject Headings) that cover popular SSH aspects and is enhanced with labels in Greek, French, Polish, German, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish and Croatian. The vocabulary is used for the automatic annotation of the publications hosted in the GoTriple platform

13.NAME: HeritageData (FISH UK) vocabularies
13.DESCRIPTION: Heritage Data – Linked Data Vocabularies for Cultural Heritage. The vocabularies have been provided by the following organisations: Historic England; Historic Environment Scotland; Royal Commission on Ancient & Historic Monuments Wales (RCAHMW). RESTful web services and user interface widgets are also available https://www.heritagedata.org/blog/resources/

14.NAME: Component Metadata Infrastructure (CMDI)
14.DESCRIPTION:
CLARIN does not offer a fixed model for metadata authoring but rather for metadata modelling – in other words, it defines a meta-model and can be thought of as a metadata framework rather than a single standard. Together with a set of core services hosted by CLARIN, the meta-model forms the basis for the Component Metadata Infrastructure (CMDI).

See CMDI is not a metadata format (or schema or vocabulary)
14.USED IN:
Various CLARIN services and repositories. 
Central metadata catalogue: Virtual Language Observatory: https://vlo.clarin.eu

15.NAME: Europeana Data Model (EDM)
15.DESCRIPTION:
[EDM was proposed for] structuring the data that Europeana
will be ingesting, managing and publishing. The Europeana Data Model is a major
improvement on the Europeana Semantic Elements (ESE), the basic data model that
Europeana began life with. (...) EDM is not built on any particular community standard but rather
adopts an open, cross-domain Semantic Web-based framework that can accommodate the
range and richness of particular community standards such as LIDO [LIDO] for museums,
EAD1 for archives or METS2 for digital libraries.

16.NAME: Data Documentation Initiative (DDI) Lifecycle
16.DESCRIPTION: DDI-Lifecycle is designed to document and manage data across the entire life cycle, from conceptualization to data publication, analysis and beyond. It encompasses all of the DDI-Codebook specification and extends it

DOMAIN.value: Social, behavioral, economic, and health sciences

17.NAME: Data Documentation Initiative (DDI) Codebook
17.DESCRIPTION: DDI-Codebook is a more light-weight version of the standard, intended primarily to document simple survey data. Originally DTD-based, DDI-C is also available as an XML Schema.

DOMAIN.value: Social, behavioral, economic, and health sciences

18.NAME: PREMIS
18.DESCRIPTION: PREMIS is an ontology used for describing the preservation of digital objects. It includes entities like objects, events, agents, and rights. PREMIS helps digital archives manage long-term preservation of digital materials by defining metadata for preservation activities and the lifecycle of digital objects.
18.USED IN: Widely used in libraries, archives, and digital repositories

19.NAME: CARARE
19.DESCRIPTION: CARARE is a metadata schema designed to support the documentation and sharing of digital archaeological and architectural heritage, especially 3D models and related data. It provides metadata for digital objects connected to archaeological sites, helping cultural heritage organizations integrate their data into Europeana.
19.USED IN: Applied in archaeological archives and for integration into Europeana

20.NAME: COCSH Ontology
20.DESCRIPTION: COSCH is an ontology that provides recommendations for the use of 3D scanning equipment in cultural heritage projects. It focuses on capturing metadata related to 3D object digitization, taking into account factors such as environmental conditions and the suitability of scanning methods for specific artifacts.
20.USED IN: Helps select appropriate scanning equipment for cultural heritage digitization

21.NAME: METS
21.DESCRIPTION: METS is a standard for encoding digital library objects and their associated metadata. It facilitates the management, storage, and transmission of complex digital objects, making it useful for digital libraries and archival systems.
21.USED IN: Used to encode and share digital objects in digital repositories

22.NAME: LIDO
22.DESCRIPTION: LIDO is a schema that enables the sharing of museum and cultural heritage object information. It is designed to support the aggregation of museum data for portals and applications. LIDO standardizes the exchange of metadata about museum objects across different platforms.
22.USED IN: Used for sharing and aggregating museum data

23.NAME: Smithsonian 3D Metadata Model
23.DESCRIPTION: The Smithsonian model is designed to meet the needs of the museum’s 3D programmes. The model documents 3D capture events (with a specific focus on photogrammetry), the digital surrogates and the raw datasets produced. Its strength is the very clear identification of which component of an object was digitised in a specific capture event and the files that were produced. It does not currently seem to cover virtual reconstructions or sources used in preparing those reconstructions. There is some take-up of the Smithsonian model by the wider community.
23.USED IN: It is used internally at the Smithsonian and is aimed at standardizing 3D capture processes like photogrammetry across different institutions​(Smithsonian Digitization Program Office).

24.NAME: STARC Metadata schema
24.DESCRIPTION: The Smithsonian model is designed to meet the needs of the museum’s 3D programmes. The model documents 3D capture events (with a specific focus on photogrammetry), the digital surrogates and the raw datasets produced. Its strength is the very clear identification of which component of an object was digitised in a specific capture event and the files that were produced. It does not currently seem to cover virtual reconstructions or sources used in preparing those reconstructions. There is some take-up of the Smithsonian model by the wider community.
24.USED IN: The schema is widely used in digital heritage projects and supports transparent communication of methodologies and decisions. The provider is STARC, and the domain is cultural heritage. You can find the documentation here​(University of Southampton).

25.NAME: DCAT
25.DESCRIPTION: DCAT is an RDF-based vocabulary to describe datasets and catalogs, promoting interoperability across different data portals.
25.USED IN: Public sector data portals, open data initiatives.

26.NAME: Schema.org
26.DESCRIPTION: A collaborative community creating, maintaining, and promoting schemas for structured data across web pages, enabling better search engine results.

27.NAME: FOAF
27.DESCRIPTION: FOAF describes people, their activities, and relationships, used in social networking and web-based applications.

28.NAME: PROV-O
28.DESCRIPTION: PROV-O is a model to represent the provenance of data, providing details about how data was produced and modified over time.
28.USED IN: Data integrity and audit trails in research and enterprise.

30.NAME: ULAN - Union List of Artist Names Online
30.DESCRIPTION: ULAN is a structured vocabulary of artist names and biographical information, used in museums and cultural institutions.
30.USED IN: Standardizing artist names in cultural heritage projects.

31.NAME: VIAF
31.DESCRIPTION: VIAF combines multiple national and regional authority files into a single service to standardize author names.
31.USED IN: Libraries, archives for author and name authority control.

32.NAME: TEI
32.DESCRIPTION: TEI provides guidelines for encoding texts in a digital format, supporting scholarly research in humanities.
32.USED IN: CLARIN (but not directly for metadata exchange)

33.NAME: DataCite schema
33.DESCRIPTION: The DataCite schema is used for generating persistent identifiers (DOIs) for datasets, helping in data citation and retrieval.
33.USED IN: Large number of prominent institutes and consorita, see https://datacite.org/members/

34.NAME: Pleiades
34.DESCRIPTION: Pleiades is a community-built resource for ancient world geography, providing data on ancient places and locations.

35.NAME: PeriodO
35.DESCRIPTION: PeriodO provides standardized period definitions, allowing for temporal alignment in historical research.

36.NAME: Scholarly Ontology
36.DESCRIPTION: Scholarly Ontology (SO) is an ontological framework for representing knowledge in the scholarly domain. It offers a flexible mechanism for modeling scholarly practices in the form of research processes that are carried out by scholars and represent their work. Modeling scholarly work with SO, allows for easy access to information, encoded in such a way that can answer questions of the form who does what, how, why, where, etc.
36.USED IN:
Research Spotlight (included in the ATRIUM portfolio)
Will be used in T4.1.3 for ontology-driven process extraction

37.NAME: Re3Data
37.DESCRIPTION: Metadata Schema for the Description of Research Data Repositories

38.NAME: TaDiRAH
38.CREATOR: Luise Borek, Canan Hastik, Vera Khramova, Jonathan Geiger
38.DESCRIPTION: Taxonomy of Digital Research Activities in the Humanities was designed to help community-driven sites and projects structure their digital humanities (DH) content and gain better visibility.TaDiRAH provides terminology for DH research activities as well as scope notes that also explain the methods associated with them. Version 2.0 linked here is a complete revision and skosification of the taxonomy. For more information and additional resources, see tadirah.info
38.USED IN: TAPoR 3; SSH Open Marketplace; European Language Grid; Agate; DH Course Registry; Bibliography Doing Digital Humanities

39.NAME: OpenAIRE guidelines
39.DESCRIPTION: Metadata schema for exchanging bibliographic information about research products of any types (publications, data, software, other)

40.NAME: FaBiO
40.DESCRIPTION: The FRBR-aligned Bibliographic Ontology (FaBiO) is an ontology for describing entities that are published or potentially publishable (e.g., journal articles, conference papers, books), and that contain or are referred to by bibliographic references.

41.NAME: BiRO
41.DESCRIPTION: The Bibliographic Reference Ontology (BiRO) is an ontology meant to define bibliographic records, bibliographic references, and their compilation into bibliographic collections and bibliographic lists, respectively.

42.NAME: HERO - Ontology of Heraldry
42.DESCRIPTION:
The heraldic ontology includes concepts used in heraldry to describe coats of arms. A coat of arms can be described with a written blazon, on the basis of which it can be drawn correctly. The blazon consists of heraldic terms that are used in accordance with established rules.
The ontology is available in several languages, even though there are certain differences in concepts and their classification between different language areas. In addition to concepts known and used generally in heraldry, the ontology includes certain rarer concepts that are associated with a specific period or language area. For example, many concepts classified as properties in HERO are not traditionally part of the Nordic heraldry.
42.USED IN: Europeana Heraldica, the heraldic database of the National Archives of Finland

43.NAME: OMA - Ontology for Media Art
43.DESCRIPTION:
OMA - Ontology for Media Art is a special ontology for media art in three languages (English, Finnish, Swedish) and it is based on General Finnish ontology YSO. OMA covers the many genres and parallel art forms of media art as well as concepts relating to technologies, materials and aesthetics of the field. Key sources used in creating the ontology include international thesauri of media art, literature and content descriptions of art works and expert consultations.
OMA Ontology was created by M-cult in context of the MEHI – the History of Media Art in Finland project coordinated by the Finnish Media Art Network in 2021-2022.

44.NAME: KTO - Ontology for Linguistics
44.PROVIDER:
PUBLISHER: National Library of Finland
CREATOR: Institute for the Languages of Finland, National Library of Finland, Semantic Computing Research Group (SeCo0, 
The Finnish Terminology Centre TSK
44.DESCRIPTION:
KTO is an ontology for linguistics originally prepared for the needs of Finnish and Finno-Ugric linguistics. The ontology is based on the Thesaurus for linguistics (2003). The languages of the ontology are Finnish, Estonian, German, and English.
KTO was established in the FinnONTO project (2003–2012), led by Aalto University and the University of Helsinki in cooperation with the Institute for the Languages of Finland (Kotus) ​​and the Finnish Terminology Centre TSK. Institute for the Languages of Finland is responsible for maintaining the content. No active development is currently being done, but the ontology is updated when necessary.

45.NAME: Lexvo - language names and ISO 639-3 language codes
45.DESCRIPTION: Lexvo provides language identifiers based on ISO 639-3, linking language names to various language resources and linguistic data.

46.NAME: IIIF
46.DESCRIPTION: IIIF defines a set of APIs to share and present digital images and manuscripts in a standardized way across different repositories.

47.NAME: Dublin Core Metadata Initiative (DCMI)
47.DESCRIPTION: DCMI is a set of metadata terms used to describe web resources, including electronic documents, that is simple yet effective.

48.NAME: OpenCitations Ontology
48.DESCRIPTION: The OpenCitations Ontology supports the description of bibliographic citation data to create open, machine-readable citation graphs.

49.NAME: MADS/RDF Primer
49.DESCRIPTION: Metadata Authority Description Schema in RDF (MADS/RDF) is used for authoritative metadata on entities like people, organizations, and events in RDF format.

50.NAME: BibFrame
50.DESCRIPTION: BibFrame is a model for bibliographic data that serves as a replacement for MARC, intended to make bibliographic data more useful on the web.

51.NAME: FRBR /LRMoo
51.DESCRIPTION: FRBR (Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records) and LRMoo (Library Reference Model Ontology) represent entities and relationships for organizing bibliographic information.

53.NAME: CiTO, the Citation Typing Ontology
53.DESCRIPTION: The Citation Typing Ontology (CiTO) is an ontology that enables characterization of the nature or type of citations, both factually and rhetorically.

54.NAME: ARCO
54.DESCRIPTION: The Augmented Representation of Cultural Objects (ARCO) defined a data model for its dynamic virtual museum system and 3D models of museum artefacts.

56.NAME: UNESCO Thesaurus
56.DESCRIPTION: The UNESCO Thesaurus is a controlled and structured list of terms used in subject analysis and retrieval of documents and publications in the fields of education, culture, natural sciences, social and human sciences, communication and information. Continuously enriched and updated, its multidisciplinary terminology reflects the evolution of UNESCO's programmes and activities.

57.NAME: Backbone Thesaurus
57.DESCRIPTION: The BBT is the research outcome of work undertaken by the DARIAH Thesaurus Maintenance WG in an effort to design and establish a coherent overarching thesaurus for the humanities, under which specialist thesauri and structured vocabularies used across scholarly communities can be aligned and form a thesaurus federation. It aims at enabling cross-disciplinary resource discovery while ensuring compatibility with thesauri that cover highly specific scientific domains and areas of knowledge in development. The BBT was created and funded by the DARIAH GR Developing a Greek Research Infrastructure for the Humanities project (2013-2015). Currently it receives funding by the APOLLONIS Greek Infrastructure for Humanities, Arts and Language Research and Innovation project (2017-2020).

58.NAME: DYAS Humanities Thesaurus
58.DESCRIPTION: The Thesaurus is the intellectual property of the Academy of Athens (AA), the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens (UOA) and the Athens School of Fine Arts (ASFA). It was created as a collaborative effort and was compiled during the course of the project DARIAH GR: Developing a Greek Research Infrastructure for Arts and Humanities (2013-2015) and of the project APOLLONIS: Greek Infrastructure for Humanities, Arts and Language Research and Innovation (2017-2020). It is maintained by the Academy of Athens. It is the outcome of an attempt to create a multilingual structured thesaurus of use to humanities scholars. It is a specialist thesaurus based on the principles, methodology and hierarchies of the BBT.

DOMAIN.value:
Anthropology and ethnology
Art and history of art

59.NAME: iDAI.world Thesaurus
59.DESCRIPTION: The iDAI.world Thesaurus brings together and harmonises all thesauri and vocabularies of the libraries and the projects of the German Archaeological Institute. It was developed between 2015 and 2019, since 2020 it is continuously updated and implemented. The core structure is based on the BBT.

60.NAME: Iconclass
60.CREATOR: Netherlands Institute for Art History
60.DESCRIPTION: Iconclass is a classification system designed for art and iconography. It is the most widely accepted scientific tool for the description and retrieval of subjects represented in images (works of art, book illustrations, reproductions, photographs, etc.) and is used by museums and art institutions around the world.

61.NAME: INDIGO Graffiti Thesaurus
61.CREATOR:
Geert Verhoeven
Massimiliano Carloni
Jona Schlegel
Stefan Wogrin
61.DESCRIPTION: The INDIGO Graffiti Thesaurus is a curated academic resource centred on contemporary graffiti terminology, with a spatial focus on the Danube Canal in Vienna, Austria. It is not just a compilation of terms, but also a specialised tool that organises and categorises graffiti-related concepts within a controlled vocabulary. More specifically, it takes the form of a thesaurus, where concepts are connected to each other through equivalence, hierarchical, and associative relationships.

62.NAME: DEFC Thesaurus
62.DESCRIPTION: The DEFC Thesaurus is a controlled vocabulary developed by the Digital Evidence and Forensics Committee to standardize terms related to digital forensics and evidence. It ensures consistency and clarity in the description and classification of digital evidence, aiding in the effective management and retrieval of forensic data.

63.NAME: OeAI Thesaurus - Cultural Time Periods
63.CREATOR: Micheline Welte
63.DESCRIPTION: This thesaurus, developed by the Austrian Academy of Sciences, provides a structured vocabulary for describing cultural time periods. It includes terms that define various historical eras, helping to categorize and contextualize cultural artifacts and events accurately.

64.NAME: OeAI Thesaurus - Materials
64.CREATOR: Micheline Welte
64.DESCRIPTION: Also from the Austrian Academy of Sciences, this thesaurus focuses on materials used in cultural heritage. It offers a standardized list of terms for different types of materials, facilitating the consistent description and classification of objects in cultural collections.

65.NAME: VICAV Taxonomy of Arabic Dialects
65.CREATOR: Charly Mörth
65.PROVIDER: Austrian Centre for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage
65.DESCRIPTION: The VICAV Taxonomy of Arabic Dialects is a classification system for the various dialects of the Arabic language. It provides a structured approach to categorizing and describing these dialects, aiding in linguistic research and the management of language-related data.

66.NAME: Vocabulary of Basic Terms for Cataloguing Costume
66.CREATOR: ICOM International Committee for the Museums and Collections of Costume
66.DESCRIPTION: The Vocabulary of Basic Terms for Cataloguing Costume is a specialized resource designed to standardize the terminology used in the documentation and cataloging of historical and contemporary costume collections. It ensures uniformity in describing garments, accessories, and related materials in museum and archive databases.

67.NAME: Cultural Objects Name Authority (CONA)
67.DESCRIPTION: CONA compiles titles, attributions, depicted subjects, and other metadata about works of art, architecture, and cultural heritage, both extant and historical, physical and conceptual. Metadata is gathered and linked from museum collections, special collections, archives, libraries, scholarly research, and other sources. CONA is linked to the AAT, TGN, ULAN, and the IA (Iconography Authority). Through rich metadata and links, CONA may provide a powerful conduit for research and discovery for digital art history. The Getty Iconography Authority (IA) includes proper names and other information for named events, themes and narratives from religion/mythology, legendary and fictional characters, works of literature and performing arts, and legendary and fictional places.

68.NAME: Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names
68.DESCRIPTION: The Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN) is a structured vocabulary that focuses on place names and geographic entities. It includes names, coordinates, and related information about historical and contemporary places. It is widely used for cataloging and metadata in art, architecture, and cultural heritage projects.

69.NAME: Archaeological Sciences Thesaurus
69.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
69.DESCRIPTION: Terminology used for recording the techniques, recovery methods and materials associated with archaeological sciences (e.g. tree-ring analysis, modification state, pathology). Maintained by Historic England on behalf of the FISH Terminology Working Group.

70.NAME: Archaeological Objects Thesaurus
70.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
70.DESCRIPTION: Originally developed by the Archaeological Objects Working Party and published by the MDA. It provides guidance for the recording of archaeological objects in Britain and Ireland covering all historical periods (e.g. corn dolly, cremation, cross). Now maintained by FISH on behalf of the heritage sector.

71.NAME: Building Materials Thesaurus
71.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
71.DESCRIPTION: Terminology used for recording the main construction materials of monuments, buildings and structures relating to the built and buried heritage of the British Isles. Includes natural/animal and man-made material (e.g. cement mix, fossil, fibre-glass). Maintained by FISH on behalf of the heritage sector.

72.NAME: Cargo Thesaurus
72.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
72.DESCRIPTION: Thesaurus for types of cargo carried by vessels and aircraft on their final voyage (e.g. animal fodder, sugar, fuel). Maintained by Historic England on behalf of the FISH Terminology Working Group.

73.NAME: Event Thesaurus
73.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
73.DESCRIPTION: Use for recording archaeological events, e.g. architectural investigative, data collection exercises; from intrusive interventions into the resource to non-damaging survey events (e.g. grab sampling, auger survey, remote sensing).

74.NAME: Evidence Thesaurus
74.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
74.DESCRIPTION: Terminology covering the existing physical remains of a monument, or the means by which a monument has been identified where no physical remains exist (e.g. placename evidence, soilmark, surface deposit).

75.NAME: Farmstead Thesaurus
75.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
75.DESCRIPTION: Thesaurus for indexing different types of farmsteads, related buildings, areas and layouts. This thesaurus does not contain any additional terminology than that held in Monument Type. Further information regarding national farm building types can be found here

76.NAME: First World War Thesaurus
76.DESCRIPTION: For the recording of monuments related to the First World War in the UK. This thesaurus was constructed for the First World War Home Front Project and does not contain any additional terminology than that held in Monument Type.

77.NAME: Heritage Crime Thesaurus
77.DESCRIPTION: Thesaurus for indexing types of crime and incidents against heritage assets (e.g. graffiti, theft, unauthorized diving).

78.NAME: Historic Aircraft Thesaurus
78.DESCRIPTION: Indexing terminology for the recording of aircraft remains and crash sites, listing aircraft types by form, function and manufacturer (e.g. Atlas, Target, Westland).

79.NAME: Thesaurus of Monument Types
79.PROVIDER: Forum on Information Standards in Heritage (FISH)
79.DESCRIPTION: Terminology relating to the built and buried heritage of the British Isles and used for recording sites, monuments, buildings and structures.

80.NAME: NeDiMAH Ontology
80.DESCRIPTION: NeMO is a CIDOC CRM - compliant ontology which explicitly addresses the interplay of factors of agency (actors and goals), process (activities and methods) and resources (information resources, tools, concepts) manifest in the scholarly process. It builds on the results of extensive empirical studies and modelling of scholarly practices performed by the Digital Curation Unit in projects DARIAH (http://www.dariah.eu/) and EHRI (http://www.ehri-project.eu/).

81.NAME: OAI-ORE
81.CREATOR: Open Archives Initiative
81.DESCRIPTION: The information made available by Nomisma.org has been provided by a wide community of scholars and institutions. All concepts published by Nomisma.org domain are openly accessible with a CC-BY license. See the Datasets page for further license statements for partner contributions to the Nomisma.org LOD ecosystem.

82.NAME: OMS
82.CREATOR: Various contributors
82.DESCRIPTION: The Open Metadata Schema (OMS) is a flexible and extensible metadata framework designed to support a wide range of digital resources. It provides a standardized way to describe and manage metadata, ensuring interoperability and ease of use across different systems.

83.NAME: MIDAS Heritage
83.CREATOR: The National Trust
83.DESCRIPTION: MIDAS Heritage is a metadata standard used in the cultural heritage sector. It provides a comprehensive framework for describing and managing information about cultural heritage objects, ensuring consistency and interoperability in the documentation and preservation of cultural assets.

84.NAME: CESSDA
84.CREATOR: CESSDA
84.DESCRIPTION: The Consortium of European Social Science Data Archives (CESSDA) provides a metadata standard for social science data. It ensures that data from social science research is described consistently, facilitating discovery, access, and reuse of social science datasets.

85.NAME: MODS
85.CREATOR: Library of Congress
85.DESCRIPTION: Metadata Object Description Schema (MODS) is a bibliographic metadata standard developed by the Library of Congress. It provides a flexible and extensible framework for describing a wide range of library resources, including books, journals, and digital objects.

86.NAME: EAD (Encoded Archival Description)
86.CREATOR: Society of American Archivists
86.DESCRIPTION: EAD is a standard for encoding archival finding aids using XML. It provides a structured way to describe archival materials, including their context, content, and structure, facilitating the discovery and management of archival collections.

87.NAME: VRA Core (Visual Resources Association Core)
87.CREATOR: Visual Resources Association
87.DESCRIPTION: VRA Core is a metadata standard developed by the Visual Resources Association for describing visual resources. It includes elements for describing the content, context, and technical aspects of images, aiding in the management and retrieval of visual materials.

88.NAME: CDWA (Categories for the Description of Works of Art)
88.CREATOR: Getty Vocabulary Program
88.DESCRIPTION: CDWA is a metadata standard for describing works of art. It provides a comprehensive set of categories for documenting the physical and contextual aspects of art objects, ensuring consistent and detailed descriptions.

89.NAME: PBCore
89.CREATOR: Public Broadcasting Metadata Group
89.DESCRIPTION: Public Broadcasting Metadata Dictionary (PBCore) is a metadata standard for describing audiovisual content. It includes elements for describing the content, format, and technical aspects of audio and video materials, facilitating their management and retrieval.

90.NAME: MEI (Music Encoding Initiative)
90.CREATOR: Music Encoding Initiative Consortium
90.DESCRIPTION: MEI is a metadata standard for encoding music notation and related materials. It provides a structured way to describe musical scores, performances, and other music-related data, ensuring consistency and interoperability in the documentation of music.

91.NAME: MARC (Machine-Readable Cataloging)
91.CREATOR: Library of Congress
91.DESCRIPTION: MARC is a standard for encoding bibliographic data in a machine-readable format. It provides a comprehensive framework for describing library materials, including books, journals, and digital resources, ensuring consistent and detailed cataloging.

92.NAME: Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH)
92.CREATOR: Library of Congress
92.DESCRIPTION: LCSH is a controlled vocabulary developed by the Library of Congress for describing the subjects of library materials. It provides a standardized list of terms for subject indexing, ensuring consistency and facilitating the retrieval of information based on subject matter.

93.NAME: Getty Thesaurus of Graphic Materials (TGM)
93.CREATOR: Getty Vocabulary Program
93.DESCRIPTION: The Getty Thesaurus of Graphic Materials (TGM) is a structured vocabulary for indexing visual materials by subject and genre/format. It includes terms for types of graphic materials, such as prints, photographs, and drawings, as well as terms for subject matter depicted in these materials. TGM is widely used in libraries, archives, and museums to facilitate the retrieval of visual resources.

94.NAME: Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC)
94.CREATOR: Melvil Dewey
94.DESCRIPTION: The Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC) is a general knowledge organization tool that is continuously revised to keep pace with knowledge. It is the world's most widely used library classification system and has been translated into numerous languages. DDC is used to organize and provide access to library collections, making it easier for users to find and retrieve information.

95.NAME: BIBO (Bibliographic Ontology)
95.CREATOR: W3C
95.DESCRIPTION: OBIBO (Bibliographic Ontology) is a formal ontology for bibliographic data, designed to provide a common framework for describing bibliographic resources. It includes classes and properties for describing various aspects of bibliographic entities, such as authors, titles, and publication dates. OBIBO aims to facilitate interoperability between different bibliographic systems and to support the development of advanced search and retrieval services.

96.NAME: CERL Thesaurus
96.CREATOR: CERL
96.DESCRIPTION: The CERL Thesaurus is a multilingual thesaurus for cultural heritage materials, developed by the Consortium of European Research Libraries (CERL). It includes terms for subjects, genres, and forms of cultural heritage materials, as well as terms for the names of persons, places, and organizations associated with these materials. The CERL Thesaurus is used to support the cataloging and retrieval of cultural heritage materials in libraries and archives.

97.NAME: FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology)
97.CREATOR: OCLC
97.DESCRIPTION: FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) is a simplified, high-level subject vocabulary derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH). It is designed to provide a more user-friendly and efficient way of applying subject headings to bibliographic records. FAST is used to support the cataloging and retrieval of library materials, as well as to facilitate the development of advanced search and retrieval services.

98.NAME: RAMEAU (Répertoire d'autorité pour les matières)
98.CREATOR: Bibliothèque nationale de France
98.DESCRIPTION: RAMEAU (Répertoire d'autorité pour les matières) is a French subject authority file developed by the Bibliothèque nationale de France (BnF). It includes terms for subjects, genres, and forms of library materials, as well as terms for the names of persons, places, and organizations associated with these materials. RAMEAU is used to support the cataloging and retrieval of library materials in French-speaking countries.

99.NAME: EuroVoc
99.CREATOR: European Parliament
99.DESCRIPTION: EuroVoc is a multilingual thesaurus developed by the European Union for indexing documents in the fields of European Union activity. It includes terms for subjects, genres, and forms of documents, as well as terms for the names of persons, places, and organizations associated with these documents. EuroVoc is used to support the cataloging and retrieval of documents in the fields of European Union activity.

100.NAME: GEMET (General Multilingual Environmental Thesaurus)
100.CREATOR: European Environment Agency
100.DESCRIPTION: GEMET (General Multilingual Environmental Thesaurus) is a multilingual thesaurus for environmental terms, developed by the European Environment Agency (EEA). It includes terms for subjects, genres, and forms of environmental materials, as well as terms for the names of persons, places, and organizations associated with these materials. GEMET is used to support the cataloging and retrieval of environmental materials in libraries, archives, and other cultural heritage organizations.

101.NAME: British Museum Object Names Thesaurus
101.CREATOR: British Museum
101.DESCRIPTION: The British Museum Object Names Thesaurus is a structured vocabulary for indexing museum objects by name. It includes terms for the names of objects, as well as terms for the materials, techniques, and functions associated with these objects. The British Museum Object Names Thesaurus is used to support the cataloging and retrieval of museum objects in the collections of the British Museum and other cultural heritage organizations.

102.NAME: SSHOC Reference Ontology
102.CREATOR: SSHOC (Social Science and Humanities Open Cloud)
102.DESCRIPTION: The SSHOC Reference Ontology is a formal ontology for social sciences and humanities data, developed by the Social Sciences and Humanities Open Cloud (SSHOC) project. It includes classes and properties for describing various aspects of social sciences and humanities data, such as research methods, data types, and data sources. The SSHOC Reference Ontology aims to facilitate interoperability between different social sciences and humanities data systems and to support the development of advanced search and retrieval services.

103.NAME: RO-Crate
103.CREATOR: RO-Crate Community
103.DESCRIPTION: RO-Crate is a community-driven standard for packaging research data and metadata. It is designed to provide a simple and flexible way of packaging research data and metadata, making it easier for researchers to share and reuse data. RO-Crate is used to support the packaging and sharing of research data in a variety of disciplines, including the social sciences, humanities, and natural sciences.

104.NAME: IA - Getty Iconography Authority
104.CREATOR: Getty Vocabulary Program
104.DESCRIPTION: The IA - Getty Iconography Authority is a structured vocabulary for indexing works of art by subject matter. It includes terms for the subjects, themes, and motifs depicted in works of art, as well as terms for the names of persons, places, and objects associated with these works. The IA - Getty Iconography Authority is used to support the cataloging and retrieval of works of art in libraries, archives, and museums.

105.NAME: RHDT Ontology (RHDTO)
105.CREATOR: PIN / ARIADNE
105.DESCRIPTION: The Reactive Heritage Digital Twin Ontology (RHDTO) is a CIDOC CRM extension for managing and interconnecting the broad range of data forming the informational core of Heritage Digital Twins. The HDT ontology is primarily designed as a tool to capture and encode information both of the tangible and intangible nature of Cultural Heritage and to provide, through specific classes and properties, a mechanism for documenting and dynamically analasing their mutual relationships. It is also designed to model their digital counterparts and the mechanisms that make them interoperable as interconnected elements within the Heritage Digital Twin.

106.NAME: NOnt
106.CREATOR: CNR Pisa (Italy)
106.DESCRIPTION: Narrative Ontology (NOnt) is a formal framework created to represent narratives in digital contexts, particularly for cultural heritage applications. It conceptualizes narratives as structured entities, including events, characters, and their temporal relationships. NOnt is implemented as an extension of three standard vocabularies: CIDOC CRM, FRBRoo, and OWL Time, utilizing the Semantic Web Rule Language (SWRL) to express its axioms. This alignment enhances interoperability across digital libraries and semantic web applications. By employing models like Allen's time algebra, NOnt effectively captures narrative complexities, facilitating efficient querying and analysis. Its formalization supports the integration of various narrative components and has been applied in tools like the Narrative Building and Visualising Tool (NBVT), which allows users to create and visualize narratives. This makes NOnt a valuable resource for researchers in literary studies and digital humanities, bridging the gap between narrative theory and technology while promoting a deeper understanding of storytelling in digital environments.

107.NAME: RIC-O
107.CREATOR: International Council on Archives
107.DESCRIPTION: RiC-O (Records in Contexts-Ontology) is an OWL ontology for describing archival record resources. As the third part of Records in Contexts standard, it is a formal representation of Records in Contexts Conceptual Model (RiC-CM).

108.NAME: OpenArchaeo Semantic Data Model
108.CREATOR: Huma-Num consortium MASA+
108.DESCRIPTION: The MASA triplestore is based on the CIDOC-CRM ontology and some of its extensions (CRMarchaeo, CRMsci and CRMba). This special selection from the CIDOC CRM ecosystem is a generic model that covers the basic concepts found in most archaeological corpuses (site, operation, structure, feature, wall, burial, stratigraphic unit and artifact).
108.USED IN: MASA+ consortium (French group of teams involved in archaeology, including INRAP)

109.NAME: PACTOLS
109.CREATOR: FRANTIQ
109.DESCRIPTION: Controlled, standardized and multilingual vocabulary for archaeology, from prehistory to the contemporary period and for the sciences of antiquity in all their aspects.
109.USED IN: Built for the CCI (Frantiq's indexed collective catalog), it is used as a thematic repository for diversified resources (academic journals, scientific databases, OpenArchaeo, ...).

110.NAME: SSH Open Marketplace Data Model
110.DESCRIPTION: The data model of the SSH Open Marketplace was designed to be generic and flexible enough to support a variety of sources.

113.NAME: CLARIN Concept Registry
113.CREATOR: CLARIN ERIC
113.DESCRIPTION: The CLARIN Concept Registry  is the place in the CLARIN Infrastructure where common and shared semantics of, but not limited to, linguistic concepts are defined. This is important to achieve semantic interoperability, and to overcome to a degree the diversity in data structures, either in metadata or linguistic resources, encountered within the infrastructure.

115.NAME: CMDI: ISO 639-3 language codes
115.CREATOR: SIL International
115.DESCRIPTION: Alpha-3 code for comprehensive coverage of languages

116.NAME: CMDI: ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country codes
116.CREATOR: ISO (?)
116.DESCRIPTION: ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 codes are two-letter country codes defined in ISO 3166-1, part of the ISO 3166 standard[1] published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO), to represent countries, dependent territories, and special areas of geographical interest.

117.NAME: CLARIN/VLO Organisations vocabulary
117.CREATOR: CLARIN ERIC
117.DESCRIPTION: Organisations and name variants (including misspellings) implemented for harmonisation purposes in the VLO

118.NAME: COAR Vocabularies
118.CREATOR: COAR
118.DESCRIPTION: The Access Rights vocabulary defines concepts to declare the access status of a resource. The Resource Type vocabulary defines concepts to identify the genre of a resource. The Version Type vocabulary defines concepts to declare the version of a resource.

119.NAME: Crossref relationship types
119.CREATOR: Crossref
119.DESCRIPTION: A set of relationship types to support the various content items that a research object, like a journal article, might link to.

121.NAME: Crossref retraction watch
121.CREATOR: Retraction Watch Database
121.DESCRIPTION: The database contains reasons for retractions gathered from publisher websites and is updated every working day by Retraction Watch.

123.NAME: CRediT (Contributor Role Taxonomy)
123.CREATOR: NISO (National Information Standards Organization)
123.DESCRIPTION: CRediT is a community-owned 14 role taxonomy that can be used to describe the key types of contributions typically made to the production and publication of research output such as research articles.

129.NAME: MORESS (Mapping of research in european social sciences and humanities)
129.CREATOR: European University Association
129.DESCRIPTION: The MOReSS vocabulary integrates data from European social sciences and humanities research databases
129.USED IN: Disciplines from Social Science and Humanities

132.NAME: EOSC Resource Life Cycle Status
132.DESCRIPTION: EOSC Life Cycle Status List from https://api.eosc-portal.eu/vocabulary/byType/LIFE_CYCLE_STATUS

131.NAME: EOSC Resource Category, Subcategory (and Supercategory)
131.DESCRIPTION: EOSC Resource Category List compiled from https://api.eosc-portal.eu/vocabulary/byType/SUPERCATEGORY, https://api.eosc-portal.eu/vocabulary/byType/CATEGORY, and https://api.eosc-portal.eu/vocabulary/byType/SUBCATEGORY

133.NAME: Intended audience
133.CREATOR: Klaus Illmayer; Creators of CESSDA Training Resources; Members of SSHOC WP6 and WP7
133.DESCRIPTION: Intended audience of an item in the SSH Open Marketplace (MP).  Parts of the vocabulary were created and are also used in the SSHOC project SSH Training Discovery Toolkit (https://training-toolkit.sshopencloud.eu). Other parts are coming from projects outside of SSHOC - e.g. CESSDA Training Resources (https://www.cessda.eu/Training-Resources) - which are additional sources for the MP to ingest items. Collections are used to assign where the concepts come from.

135.NAME: Invocation type
135.CREATOR: SSHOC project WP3; SSHOC project WP7
135.DESCRIPTION: Gives information about how something (usually a tool or service) is invocated.  Used in Conversion Hub in the context of solutions and in Open Marketplace for all types of items but mainly for tools and services (property 'mode-of-use').

137.NAME: SSH Open Marketplace Keyword
137.DESCRIPTION: All the keywords used in the SSH Open Marketplace: coming from various sources.

138.NAME: IANA Media Types
138.DESCRIPTION: List of all Media Types from IANA with 9 top levels and all concepts below

139.NAME: ÖFOS 2012. Austrian Fields of Science and Technology Classification 2012
139.CREATOR: Statistics Austria; Christoph Hoffmann (skos/rdf version)
139.PROVIDER: Austrian Centre for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage
139.DESCRIPTION: The Austrian Fields of Science and Technology Classification (ÖFOS 2012) is the Austrian version of the revised international Fields of Science and Technology Classification of the OECD (FOS) published in the Frascati Manual 2015 as Fields of Research and Development (FORD). These fields are adjusted to national needs, whose application for international comparisons is binding, particularly within the European Statistical System. The six major Fields of Science: Natural Sciences; Technical Sciences; Human Medicine, Health Sciences; Agricultural Sciences, Veterinary Medicine; Social Sciences and Humanities remained unchanged in comparison to ÖFOS 2002. In order to ensure international comparability, the previous 2-digit levels from 2002, which are no longer applicable, were replaced by new 3-digit levels (groups) according to the international FOS respectively FORD. These 3-digit levels were provided with further sub-groups (4-digits) taking into account the comments of the international classification. It is therefore feasible that the new Austrian Fields of Science adapt to national peculiarities of the Austrian research activities. The research area with the corresponding 6-digits in alphabetical order serves as a description of the fields of activities and research projects and/or for the coverage of the main scientific activities of a statistical unit in the research and development surveys. (Current revision status: August 2017)

140.NAME: SPDX Software License
140.CREATOR: https://sshoc.poolparty.biz/user/superadmin; https://sshoc.poolparty.biz/user/karampatakiss
140.DESCRIPTION: The SPDX License List itself is a list of commonly found licenses and exceptions used in free and open or collaborative software, data, hardware, or documentation.

142.NAME: SSK Standard
142.DESCRIPTION: A list of standards that are mentioned in steps of the SSK (Standardization Survival Kit)

148.NAME: BIBO Publication Type
148.DESCRIPTION: The Bibliographic Ontology describes bibliographic things on the semantic Web in RDF. This ontology can be used as a citation ontology, as a document classification ontology, or simply as a way to describe any kind of document in RDF. It has been inspired by many existing document description metadata formats, and can be used as a common ground for converting other bibliographic data sources.  This version only takes the relevant concepts used in the SSH Open Marketplace (and introducing a new concept pre-print).

150.NAME: SSH Open Marketplace Format
150.DESCRIPTION: List of formats to chose from in SSH Open Marketplace

153.NAME: Nomisma Ontology
153.CREATOR: Various Institutions
153.DESCRIPTION: Nomisma.org is an international, collaborative project to provide stable digital representations of numismatic concepts according to the principles of Linked Open Data (LOD). These take the form of HTTP URIs that also provide access to reusable information about those concepts, along with links to other resources. The Nomisma.org community maintains a formalized RDF Ontology and a data model for encoding concepts, coins, typologies, hoards, and other types of numismatic objects as LOD.

159.NAME: VoID (Vocabulary of Interlinked Datasets)
159.CREATOR: W3C Interest Group
159.DESCRIPTION: VoID is an RDF Schema vocabulary for expressing metadata about RDF datasets. VoID can be used to express general metadata based on Dublin Core, access metadata, structural metadata, and links between datasets.

161.NAME: World Historical Gazetteer
161.PROVIDER: World History Center, University of Pittsburgh
